repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: In 12 manuscript boxes and 2 oversize boxes

did.abstract: Thomas "Tom" Moran (1944-2012) was born and raised in New York City in an Irish-American working-class family. As shop steward of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America (UWUA), and later as safety director, Moran fought for workers' rights to a safe and healthy workplace, clashing with Con Edison over radiation exposure, asbestos, PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls), clean air, lead, and other instances of worker exposure to toxic substances without warning. Involved in several New York State Supreme Court cases as a plaintiff on behalf of UWUA, Moran represented workers in their struggle for workplace protections, legal enforcement, and provisions for protective equipment and preventive training. This collection, spanning Moran's work from 1975 to 1993, contains court records, correspondence with government bodies and advocacy groups, technical manuals, health and safety training materials, and citations given to Con Edison by regulatory bodies. These materials were collected by Moran in the course of his work as Safety Director for the UWUA and represent the issues, cases, training materials, and litigation related to the workplace safety of UWUA members working for Con Edison.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Thomas "Tom" Moran was born and raised in New York City (1944-2012) in an Irish-American working-class family. Moran was a shop steward for Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America (UWUA) for much of his career in the labor movement. His father, uncle, and brother all worked for Con Edison, and his father helped lead the UWUA's union drive; Tom joined them in the ranks of the company in 1966. As shop steward of Local 1-2, and later as safety director, Moran fought for workers' rights to a safe and healthy workplace, clashing with Con Edison over radiation exposure, asbestos, PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls), clean air, lead, and other instances of worker exposure to toxic substances without warning. Involved in several New York State Supreme Court cases as a plaintiff on behalf of UWUA, Moran represented workers in their struggle for workplace protections, legal enforcement, and provisions for protective equipment and preventive training. He developed close working relationships with politicians across New York State, lobbying connections for stronger labor protections and sanctions for environmental violations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in four series: Seris I. Legal Documents; Series II. Correspondence; Series III. Worker Records; Series VI. Technical Materials. Files have been arranged in chronological order within each series.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Thomas Moran were transferred to New York University in 2000 by Thomas Moran. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in Box 13 contain Protected Health Information (PHI) and are restricted until 50 years after the death of the individual in question.
Materials in Box 14 contain Personal Identifiable Information and are restricted until 2039.
The remaining materials in the collection are open without restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Thomas Moran Papers; WAG 166; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Thomas Moran in 2000. The accession number associated with this gift is 2000.012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Thomas Moran Papers (1975-1993) document Moran's involvement in the labor movement in New York State, with specific regards to his years-long fight for workers' health and safety in utility professions. Beginning his career as a shop steward for Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Unionof America (UWUA) and eventually rising to the role of Safety Director, the documents in this collection trace Moran's involvement in various legal campaigns against hazardous substances as a violation of workers' rights.

Documents in this collection address Moran's involvement in three New York State Supreme Court cases: Ostrowski v. Local 1-2 (1980), State of New York v. Consolidated Edison, Inc. (1982-1986), and Moran v. Vaccaro (1989). These cases deal with workers' wrongful exposure to asbestos without appropriate warning or protections, themes echoed in much of the collection in sum. The files regarding Ostrowski v. Local 1-2 and State of New York v. Consolidated Edison contain documents filed in court by the plaintiffs and defendants including motions, affidavits, judgments, and subpoenas. Files for Moran v. Vaccaro contain official court documents as well Moran's original whistleblower complaint and narratives written by doctors regarding injuries sustained by Con Ed employees. Supporting documentation submitted as evidence is overwhelmingly represented through citations issued to Con Edison by the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA), hazardous materials testing and monitoring reports compiled in response to complaints, and individual complaints filed by Moran himself.

Moran's working relationships other key stakeholders in the area of workplace safety is documented by correspondence with government bodies and advocacy groups, notably with Nancy Stearns of the New York Attorney General's Office. This correspondence highlights the existence and enforcement of New York's 1980 "Right to Know Law," which stated that employers had to alert employees to the possibility of exposure to hazardous materials in the workplace and provide appropriate information on protective gear and safety and also documents lobbying work done by Moran and others, including lawyers he also engaged to represent him in litigation, regarding other workplace safety laws and regulations. Letters from Moran to Janet Fox, director of Safety Services at Con Edison, also evidence of how Moran utilized Local 1-2's legal right to request information on sample analysis reports that could prove illegal substance exposure.
This collection also contains safety guides and technical manuals that document the workplace safety issues which concerned Local 1-2 workers throughout Moran's career.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: A graduate student in the Fall 2019 session of Advanced Archival Description HIST-GA.2031 surveyed and wrote a processing plan for this collection. This collection was arranged and described by an archivist in the fall of 2021. Materials were placed in new acid-free folders and boxes; folder titles were retained where possible.
File titles were reviewed by the processing archivist and when identified as restricted, were physically separated and stored in shared restricted boxes.

controlaccess.subject: Industrial safety -- New York (State) -- New York

New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health
Utility Workers Union of America. Local 1-2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series traces Thomas Moran's involvement in three New York State Supreme Court cases: Ostrowski v. Local 1-2 (1980), State of New York v. Consolidated Edison, Inc. (1982-1986) and Moran v. Vaccaro (1989). The documents in this series span a variety of phases of the cases' progress through the courts, including briefs from plaintiffs and defendants at multiple injunctions, correspondence between the New York State Attorney General's office and plaintiffs, and plaintiff affidavits. The initial letter to the plaintiffs in Moran v. Vaccaro and the forms accompanying the letter, including a questionnaire for plaintiffs surveying their medical history and details of exposure, is a significant document that frames much of the surrounding legal documentation although no completed questionnaires are included. A written statement from Richard Ostrowski, shop steward for Local 1-2, on his illegal removal from stewardship in retaliation for organizing around issues of radiation exposure, is also included.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in Box 13 contain Protected Health Information (PHI) and are restricted until 50 years after the death of the individual in question.
Materials in Box 14 contain Personal Identifiable Information and are restricted until 2039.

did.unittitle: Ostrowski v. Utility Workers United of America
State of New York v. Consolidated Edison, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Moran's correspondence with government bodies, advocacy groups, and lawyers concerning his work advocating for worker safety issues, specifically enforcement of New York state's 1980 "Right to Know Law," which states that employers have to alert employees to the possibility of exposure to hazardous materials in the workplace. The correspondence with lawyers and law firms in this series relates to Moran's advocacy work rather than any particular litigation. Of particular note are the initial letters between Moran and Janet Fox, director of Safety Services at Con Edison, in which Moran begins the process of requesting all asbestos variance reports to compile evidence for impending litigation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in Box 14 contain Personal Identifiable Information and are restricted until 2039.

physdesc.extent: In 2 manuscript boxes and two flat boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents worker grievances and reports of health and safety violations at Con Edison worksites. Documents represent complaints filed with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA), worker complaints surrounding specific Con Edison worksites such as Indian Point and Gramercy Park, and safety grievances filed by Local 1-2 members. These complaints are overwhelmingly represented through citations issued to Con Edison by OSHA, hazardous materials testing and monitoring reports compiled in response to complaints, and individual complaints filed by Thomas Moran himself. This series also contains reports from the Bureau of Labor Statistics that compile instances of workplace safety violations at Con Edison worksites from 1987, 1988, and 1989.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in Box 13 contain Protected Health Information (PHI) and are restricted until 50 years after the death of the individual in question.
Materials in Box 14 contain Personal Identifiable Information and are restricted until 2039.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV consists of handbooks, safety manuals, safety guidelines, and other materials produced by health and safety organizations including the Environmental Protection Agency, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, City Department of Environmental Variance, National Lighting Bureau, and the New York Committee for Occupation Safety and Health. The contents cover a variety of hazardous substances and related issues that affected members of Local 1-2: radiation exposure, asbestos, PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls), clean air, lead, pole-mounted transformers, fiberglass wool insulation, cumulative trauma disorders, electrical safety, cadmium, oxygen masks, electromagnetic fields, trench excavation, fire prevention, industrial hygiene, lighting, and others.

did.unittitle: Environmental Protection Agency Guidance for Controlling Asbestos Containing Materials in Buildings
City of New York Department of Environmental Protection--Asbestos Variance
